questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He had a history of contact with multiple sexual partners. He was diagnosed as HIV positive 6 months back and is poorly adherent to his medications. The fungal culture of sputum was negative. On Gomori methamine silver staining, the cells showed darkly stained crescent-shaped cysts. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumocystis jerovecii

 

The given scenario is pointing out to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis (aka South American blastomycosis • Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease), presents with oral mucosa lesions, cervical lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary lesions.

 

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, systemic granulomatous disease. On GMS staining, shows tiny oval yeast cells (2–4 µm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

 

Option C. Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, around 60% patients are asymptomatic. Manifests as pneumonia, cavities, pleural effusion or nodule formation, Skin lesions, Arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a critical opportunistic infection in HIV/AIDS patients, characterized by non-specific respiratory symptoms and distinctive cystic structures on Gomori methenamine silver staining. Regular prophylaxis and monitoring are essential for at-risk populations.

questions.text: Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inflammation without purulent discharge

 

MULTIFOCAL NON-SUPPURATIVE OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Focal sterile inflammatory disease with prolonged, self-limiting and recurring episodes.
  • It is an auto-inflammatory disorder that causes bone pain due to inflammation in the bones not caused by infection. 
  • It has been associated with SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, palmo-plantar Hyperostosis and Osteitis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Tenderness in affected area
    • Some patients may develop arthritis
    • Fatigue
    • Chronic pain affecting quality of life
    • Delayed growth in some children
    • Night bone pain
    • Regional palpable swelling over bones with little overlying soft tissue
       
  • Despite the local and systemic signs of inflammation, there is no purulent discharge and microbes are seldom isolated. This is a diagnosis of exclusion.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Mildly elevated CRP and ESR
    • Positive ANA and HLA-B27
    • Elevated serum cytokines
    • Mildly elevated serum TNF-alpha and IL-6
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray shows lytic bone lesions, sclerosis and hyperostosis.
    • MRI is the investigation of choice
    • Whole body MRI provides information about lesion distribution, soft tissue involvement, and/or possible involvement of additional organs
    • Bone biopsy reveals dense infiltrates of immune cells, bone lysis, fibrosis, and/or normal bone.
       
  • Treatment:
    • NSAIDs are first-line agents for quick symptomatic relief and control inflammation
    • Corticosteroids, DMARDs, anti-TNF agents, and bisphosphonates are effective in some patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by inflammation without any purulent discharge.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition given in the graph? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Non-competitive

 

The above given graph is showing non-competitive inhibition.

 

When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

 

In this curve, the Km is constant but the Vmax has decreased.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Competitive: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site. This increases the apparent Km (the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases), but Vmax remains unchanged. The Lineweaver-Burk plot would show a change in slope and the same Y-intercept.

 

Option B. Uncompetitive: In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the complex from releasing products. This decreases both Km and Vmax. The Lineweaver-Burk plot would show parallel lines (same slope) with different Y-intercepts.

 

Option D. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves inhibitors binding to an allosteric site, which can cause non-competitive inhibition if it changes the enzyme's conformation. However, the specific graph in the question fits the description of non-competitive inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given graph illustrates non-competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds to an allosteric site, causing a decrease in Vmax while Km remains constant. This type of inhibition affects the enzyme's activity without altering the substrate's binding affinity.

questions.text: A patient had a renal tumor and brain tumor with multiple members in the family being affected in previous generations. Which of the following is the likely gene involved in this individual? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VHL gene

 

The clinical presentation of renal tumors, brain tumors, and a strong family history of similar tumors suggests Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome.

 

VHL syndrome is a genetic condition caused by mutations in the VHL gene located on chromosome 3.

 

It is characterized by the development of various types of tumors, including clear cell renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system (particularly in the cerebellum), and pheochromocytomas.

 

Patients with VHL syndrome are at increased risk for these tumors, and the condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, explaining the presence of multiple affected family members.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RET gene: The RET gene is associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), which primarily involves medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid adenomas. It is not linked with renal or brain tumors.

 

Option B. TSC gene: The TSC gene is related to Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, which is associated with benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, heart, and kidneys. However, it is characterized by epilepsy, skin manifestations, and cardiac tumors, which are not the main features presented in this question.

 

Option D. Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Li-Fraumeni syndrome is caused by mutations in the TP53 gene and is characterized by a broad spectrum of cancers, including soft tissue sarcomas, osteosarcomas, brain tumors, breast cancer, and leukemias. However, it does not specifically target the combination of brain and renal tumors seen in VHL syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is associated with renal cell carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioblastomas, and pheochromocytomas, and it is caused by mutations in the VHL gene on chromosome 3.

choices.text: Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Isthmus because of narrowest area
Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Ampulla because of narrowest area

questions.text: The most common site of tubal ligation and the reason for ligation at this site is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isthmus because of narrowest area

 

The most common site for tubal ligation is the isthmus of the fallopian tube. The isthmus is the narrowest portion of the tube, which makes it an ideal site for ligation. One key reason for selecting this site is that it preserves the broader segments of the tube, such as the ampulla, which are essential if recanalization (reversal of the ligation) is needed later. By ligating the narrowest part, the wider and more functionally significant areas remain intact, facilitating easier and more successful surgical reanastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: This is incorrect because the reason for ligating at the isthmus is primarily its narrowness, not muscle structure.

 

Option C. Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: The ampulla is not the preferred site for ligation because it is wider and more functionally significant. Ligation here would complicate future recanalization procedures.

 

Option D. Ampulla because of narrowest area: This is incorrect because the ampulla is not the narrowest part of the fallopian tube; the isthmus is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus is the most common site for tubal ligation due to its narrowness, which preserves the broader, more functional parts of the tube, making recanalization easier if needed in the future.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following aortic arches causes the defect shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 6th left

 

The image depicts a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

 

Normally, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. However, in cases of PDA, the ductus arteriosus fails to close, leading to abnormal blood flow between the two major arteries.

 

Presentation - Hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

 

Treatment options for PDA include medication, minimally invasive catheter-based procedures, and surgical closure. Medications like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be given to encourage closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

The aortic arch arteries, also referred to as the branchial or pharyngeal arch arteries, are a series of six paired arterial structures that arise from the aortic sac during embryonic development. They play a crucial role in the formation of the major arteries of the head, neck, and thorax. Abnormal development or persistence of these arteries can lead to a range of congenital anomalies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 4th left and Option B. 4th right: These arches are primarily involved in forming parts of the aorta and its major branches, not directly related to the defect depicted in the image.

 

Option D. 6th right: While the right 6th arch also contributes to the development of the pulmonary artery system, its defects are usually not associated with PDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here's a list of defects related to the aortic arch arteries:

 

  1. Double Aortic Arch: This involves the persistence of both the right and left fourth aortic arches. It can form a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus, which can cause respiratory and feeding difficulties.
  2. Right Aortic Arch: This results from the regression of the left fourth aortic arch. Depending on the persistence of the ductus arteriosus, different types can form, some of which can lead to a vascular ring.
  3. Interrupted Aortic Arch: Here, there's a complete loss of continuity between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta. It's often associated with other congenital heart defects.
  4. Persistent Truncus Arteriosus: This is a failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta, leading to a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart supplying both systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations.
  5. Coarctation of the Aorta: It's a narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the site of the ductus arteriosus. It can lead to high blood pressure in the upper body and arms and lower blood pressure in the lower body and legs.
  6. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes, but in this condition, it remains open, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery.
  7. Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery: This is a variant in the branching pattern where the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch and can course posterior to the esophagus.
  8. Cervical Aortic Arch: Here, the aortic arch is positioned higher than normal in the neck. It is usually of no clinical significance but can be identified radiologically.
  9. Aortopulmonary Septal Defects: These defects involve abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  10. Vascular Rings: These are congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches that encircle and compress the trachea and esophagus.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Scala tympani

 

The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the Scala tympani.

 

A cochlear implant works by producing meaningful electrical stimulation of the auditory nerve where degeneration of the hair cells in the cochlea has progressed to a point such that amplification provided by hearing aids is no longer effective.

 

The principle of cochlear implant surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. This allows the electrodes to be in close proximity to the spiral ganglion cells and their dendrites (that lie in the modiolus and osseous spiral lamina of the cochlea, respectively).

 

There are broadly two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation:

 

  1. The facial recess approach where a simple cortical mastoidectomy is done. The facial recess is opened by performing a posterior tympanotomy. The stapes, promontory and round window niche are identified. Cochleostomy is then performed anteroinferior to the round window membrane to a diameter of 1.0 - 1.6 mm depending on the electrode to be used.
  2. The pericanal techniques where a tympanomeatal flap is elevated to perform a cochleostomy either by endaural or postaural approach. In the pericanal techniques a bony tunnel is drilled along the external canal towards the middle ear. The examples of pericanal techniques include the Veria and suprameatal recess approach.

 

The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Round window - Not typically the site for electrode placement in cochlear implants.

 

Option B. Oval window - Also not used for electrode placement; this structure connects the middle ear to the inner ear.

 

Option C. Scala vestibuli - Another perilymph-filled cavity in the cochlea, but not the preferred location for electrode placement due to its anatomy and relation to the auditory pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scala tympani is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery to ensure optimal auditory nerve stimulation, highlighting the importance of precision in surgical approaches to maximize the benefits of the implant.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On US, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

 

  • Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like
    • B/l renal agenesis
    • B/l dysplastic kidneys
    • B/l Autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal anemia: Severe fetal anemia also can cause hydrops and polyhydramnios like in Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome and Rh iso-immunization

 

Option C. Barter syndrome and option D. Anencephaly cause polyhydramnios

 

Educational Objective

 

Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral dysplastic kidneys, or bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease.

 

Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which ion channels are defective in CFTR gene mutation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cl-

 

The CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene mutation primarily affects chloride ion channels. In cystic fibrosis, the defective CFTR gene leads to the malfunctioning of these chloride channels, which are crucial for maintaining the balance of salt and water on epithelial surfaces such as the lungs and the pancreas. This malfunction results in the production of thick and sticky mucus, leading to the various symptoms associated with cystic fibrosis. The normal functioning CFTR protein allows chloride ions to move in and out of cells, regulating the water content in mucus and other secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Incorrect. While sodium ion transport can be indirectly affected by the dysfunctional chloride channels, the primary defect in cystic fibrosis is related to chloride ions.

 

Option C. K+: Incorrect. Potassium channels are not directly affected by the CFTR gene mutation. The primary defect is specific to chloride ion channels.

 

Option D. Ca2+: Incorrect. Calcium channels are not directly impacted by mutations in the CFTR gene. The main issue in cystic fibrosis lies with chloride ion transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CFTR gene mutations cause defects in chloride ion channels, leading to the symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

choices.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends
﻿﻿﻿At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

 

Explanation:

 

Incorrect. Late decelerations are defined by a decrease in fetal heart rate that is typically more than 15 beats per minute below the baseline and is not defined by a specific frequency above baseline. The characteristic depth and timing of the deceleration are more important than the number of beats or frequency above the baseline.

 

Late decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns are important indicators of fetal well-being and uteroplacental function. late decelerations are indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency. Understanding their characteristics is crucial for accurate assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: Correct. Late decelerations start after the peak of the uterine contraction and end after the contraction has concluded. This delayed onset and resolution are key features.

 

Option B. They are smooth and gradual: Correct. Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth and gradual decline in fetal heart rate (FHR).

 

Option D. Not associated with accelerations: Correct. Late decelerations are not typically associated with accelerations. This differentiates them from other types of decelerations, such as early decelerations, which can be accompanied by accelerations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth, gradual decline in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of a uterine contraction and returns to baseline after the contraction ends, and they are not defined by beats above baseline or associated with accelerations.

 

Ref: Page 693, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the skin is false ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dermis is derived from ectoderm

 

Dermis is derived from mesoderm and epidermis is derived from ectoderm.

 

  • The epidermis is derived from the ectoderm, which is one of the three primary germ layers that form during embryonic development.
  • The ectoderm gives rise to the skin, hair, nails, and the nervous system.
  • The epidermis itself is formed by the surface ectoderm, which begins to thicken and form a layer of cells called the basal layer.
  • On the other hand, the dermis is derived from the mesoderm, which is another one of the primary germ layers.
  • The mesoderm gives rise to a number of different structures in the body, including muscles, bones, and connective tissue.
  • The dermis itself is formed from the mesenchymal cells that migrate into the developing skin from the mesoderm.
  • These cells differentiate into fibroblasts, which then produce the extracellular matrix that forms the dermis.
  • During development, the epidermis and dermis layers interact and become tightly integrated.
  • As the epidermis differentiates, it sends signals to the underlying mesenchymal cells to produce the dermis, and the two layers eventually become fully functional together as the skin.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight: This statement is generally accurate. In adults, the skin weighs about 8-10 pounds and has a surface area of about 2 square meters. The skin is the largest organ of the body, and its weight can be roughly estimated to be around 15% of the total body weight, although this can vary based on individuals and their body compositions.

 

Option C. Epidermis is derived from ectoderm: This statement is true. The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin and is indeed derived from the ectoderm during embryonic development. It's a stratified squamous epithelium that mainly consists of keratinocytes in progressive stages of differentiation, from the basal layer to the surface. The epidermis provides the body with a barrier against pathogens, UV radiation, and water loss.

 

Option D. Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen: This statement is true. The dermis, which provides the skin's strength and elasticity, primarily consists of type 1 collagen, but it also contains a smaller amount of type 3 collagen, especially in the papillary dermis (the uppermost layer of the dermis). These collagens are essential for skin's resilience and durability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermis is derived from the mesoderm, not the ectoderm.

questions.text: The heart of the 'Activated sludge process' method is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aeration tank

 

The Activated Sludge Process is a crucial method in the secondary treatment of sewage. The process primarily focuses on the biological treatment of wastewater to remove organic matter effectively. The key component, or the "heart," of this process is the aeration tank.

 

Process flow of the activated sludge method:

 

The aeration tank is central to the activated sludge process, where the wastewater is aerated to facilitate the breakdown of organic material by microorganisms.

 

Treatment Stages:

 

  • Primary Treatment: Involves primary sedimentation, where solids settle out before the wastewater moves to the aeration tank.
  • Secondary Treatment: Comprises the aeration tank for further biological treatment and final settling tanks for secondary sedimentation. Wastewater spends about 6 to 8 hours in the aeration tank, allowing for sufficient microbial action. In the secondary sedimentation stage, the retention time is approximately 2 to 3 hours to allow solids to settle out effectively.

 

Recirculation of Effluent: About 20 to 30 percent of the effluent is recirculated from the secondary sedimentation back to the aeration tank. This recycling helps maintain adequate microbial populations in the aeration tank to enhance the treatment process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary sedimentation tank: This tank is part of the primary treatment process, where larger solids settle out before the sewage enters the aeration tank. It is not the heart of the Activated Sludge Process, which occurs during secondary treatment.

 

Option C. Anaerobic digestion: This process is typically used for sludge treatment, not for the main biological treatment of wastewater.

 

Option D. Secondary sedimentation tank: While this tank is involved in the final stage of the Activated Sludge Process, where the sludge settles out, it is not the heart of the process. The critical biological activity happens in the aeration tank.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The aeration tank is the central component of the Activated Sludge Process, where aerobic bacteria break down organic pollutants in wastewater.

questions.text:
Correct sequence after p wave: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

A- 'a' wave

B- 1st heart sound

C-Rapid filling of ventricles

D- 't' wave
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABDC

 

Following the P wave, which represents atrial depolarization leading to atrial contraction:

 

A- 'a' wave occurs as a result of atrial contraction, pushing blood into the ventricles.

 

B- 1st heart sound is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of ventricular systole.

 

D- 't' wave represents the repolarization of the ventricles, indicating the beginning of ventricular relaxation.

 

C- Rapid filling of ventricles follows as the ventricles relax and the atrioventricular valves open, allowing blood to flow from the higher pressure atria to the relaxed ventricles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical events precede mechanical events in cardiac homeostasis

 

P wave→ Atrial contraction (a wave).

 

QRS→ ventricular contraction (C wave)

 

T wave→ Ventricular relaxation (Early rapid filling (Y descent)

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Clinical/ chap 239

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orgasm

 

This phase involves the release of sexual tension. Premature ejaculation and anorgasmia are disorders of this phase.

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It involves ejaculation that occurs earlier than desired, often with minimal sexual stimulation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Desire: This phase refers to the interest in engaging in sexual activity. Disorders of this phase might manifest as hypoactive sexual desire disorder or sexual aversion disorder.

 

Option B. Arousal: This phase is characterized by physiological changes such as erection in men and vaginal lubrication in women. Erectile dysfunction is a disorder of this phase in men.

 

Option D. Pain: This isn't a phase of the sexual response cycle. However, dyspareunia refers to pain during intercourse and can be a clinical condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of the sexual response cycle. It is characterized by a pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after the vaginal penetration.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 579.

questions.text: A patient was started on Amitryptiline and he was found to be unconscious. Which of the following doesn’t suggest TCA toxicity ?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

TCA toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia due to anticholinergic effects, not hypothermia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias: Arrhythmias are a hallmark of TCA toxicity, reflecting its impact on cardiac conductivity.

 

Option B. Confusion: Confusion or altered sensorium is common due to the central nervous system effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. Pupillary dilatation: Pupillary dilatation results from the anticholinergic properties of TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of TCA toxicity, we see symptoms like arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilatation due to its anticholinergic and cardiotoxic properties. Hypothermia is not typically associated with TCA overdose.

choices.text: TPE removes the von Willebrand factor
TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is caused by a deficiency of ADAMTS13, usually due to autoantibodies. Total plasma exchange (TPE) removes these autoantibodies, thereby increasing ADAMTS13 protease activity and preventing the accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers. This results in platelet trapping. Classic clinical picture includes:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • End-organ damage (neurological injury)
  • Fever

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. TPE removes the von Willebrand factor: Incorrect; the goal is to remove autoantibodies.
 

Option B. TPE removes the antiplatelet antibodies: Incorrect; TTP involves anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies.
 

Option C. TPE replenishes the coagulation factors: Incorrect; TTP is not primarily a coagulation factor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

choices.text: Non vigorous baby
Rh negative mother

questions.text: When should early cord clamping be done? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non vigorous baby

 

Early cord clamping should be done primarily when the baby is non-vigorous/ hypoxic baby i.e. not breathing, or not crying at birth. Immediate neonatal resuscitation is required in such cases to address the baby's urgent need for oxygen and support.

 

Delaying cord clamping in a non-vigorous baby could waste crucial time needed for resuscitation efforts. According to WHO guidelines, the only absolute contraindication to delayed cord clamping is a non-vigorous baby.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rh negative mother: Although older guidelines suggested early cord clamping in Rh-negative mothers to reduce the risk of fetomaternal hemorrhage, current guidelines do not strongly recommend this practice. The benefits of delayed cord clamping, such as reducing anemia in the baby, outweigh the potential risks.

 

Option C. Preterm: For preterm babies, delayed cord clamping is recommended to help prevent anemia and improve blood volume. Preterm infants benefit significantly from the additional blood received during delayed clamping.

 

Option D. Pre-eclampsia: Pre-eclampsia is not a contraindication for delayed cord clamping. Delayed clamping can still provide the newborn with additional blood and help prevent anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early cord clamping is indicated for non-vigorous babies who require immediate resuscitation efforts.

choices.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics
Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

 

In the given clinical scenario, it is important to establish or rule out a diagnosis of HIV infection before evaluating for secondary infections. Therefore, the next best step is to obtain a dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR. AIDS enteropathy, a syndrome of malabsorption with partial villous atrophy not associated with a specific pathogen, has been postulated to be a result of direct HIV infection of the gut.

 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in infants born to HIV-infected mothers is done using various methods, including HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program now uses an HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

 

Infants born to HIV-positive mothers should be exclusively breastfed or fed with replacement feeds exclusively until 6 months of age. Infants should also receive AR prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine.

 

It is common for HIV-infected infants to experience gastrointestinal tract involvement, with bacteria (Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella, Mycobacterium avium complex), protozoa (Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Isospora, microsporidia), viruses (CMV, HSV, rotavirus), and fungi (Candida) being common pathogens. MAC and protozoal infections tend to be the most severe and prolonged in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Test stool for giardiasis and give antibiotics: This is not the preferred immediate next step. First, the diagnosis of HIV infection should be established before treating secondary infections.

 

Option C. Antibody tests for HIV: Antibody tests for HIV are not useful in establishing the diagnosis of HIV infection in infants. This is because all infants born to HIV-infected mothers test antibodies positive at birth due to the passive transfer of maternal HIV antibodies across the placenta. It can be used as a diagnostic tool after 18 months of age.

 

Option D. Aerobic culture: Aerobic culture is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection. It is more relevant for identifying bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

choices.text: Pulmonary arterial hypertension

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Constrictive pericarditis

 

The key clinical feature in this scenario is Kussmaul's sign, which is the paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure (JVP) during inspiration. This is indicative of conditions that impede the normal inspiratory decrease in JVP, such as constrictive pericarditis.

 

Key Features of Constrictive Pericarditis:

 

  • Kussmaul's Sign: Lack of normal inspiratory decrease in JVP, or paradoxical increase, due to rigid pericardium that limits cardiac filling.
  • Dyspnea: Common due to impaired filling of the heart.
  • Absence of Murmur: Distinguishes it from valvular heart diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation typically presents with a diastolic murmur and does not cause Kussmaul's sign.

 

Option C. Tricuspid stenosis: Tricuspid stenosis can cause elevated JVP, but it is usually associated with a diastolic murmur.

 

Option D. Pulmonary arterial hypertension: Pulmonary arterial hypertension can cause elevated JVP, but it is not typically associated with Kussmaul's sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kussmaul's sign, an increase in JVP on inspiration, is indicative of constrictive pericarditis. It is not associated with murmurs or primary valvular heart diseases.

questions.text: External beam radiotherapy uses: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Co60

 

External beam radiotherapy, a cornerstone in the treatment of various cancers, utilizes high-energy beams to target and destroy cancer cells.

 

Co60 is a common radioisotope used in external beam radiotherapy due to its high-energy gamma rays, which are effective at penetrating tissues to treat tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cobalt-59 (Co59): Co59 is not used in radiation therapy; it is a stable isotope of cobalt.

 

Option C. Strontium: Strontium isotopes (like Sr-89) are used in the treatment of bone metastases, not typically in external beam radiotherapy. They help alleviate pain by targeting cancerous cells in the bone.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus (typically P-32) is used in radiopharmaceuticals for treating specific types of blood disorders and polycythemia vera, not in external beam radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

EBRT uses Cobalt 60 as the radioisotope.

questions.text: A study involved 30,000 women who were monitored for a period of 10 years to track the occurrence of breast cancer. Among them, 1200 women developed cancer and were subsequently given a questionnaire to evaluate potential risk factors. In parallel, 2000 women from the same study served as controls and were also subjected to the questionnaire. What is the name of this type of study? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Nested case control

 

  • Given scenario dictates that a population was monitored for development of breast cancer.
  • Out of which, 1200 women developed breast cancer and a small subgroup was taken as control.
  • This study structure points to Nested case control study.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Cohort study involves selecting Exposed and non-exposed groups then follow them for development of outcome.

 

Option B. Retrospective cohort: In Retrospective cohort, the outcomes have already occurred before the study begins.

 

Option D. Cross control cohort: Cross control cohort is not a study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A nested case-control study involves identifying cases and controls from an existing cohort that is being followed over time, making it a cost-effective way to study the associations between exposures and outcomes.

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter

questions.text: The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

 

The best indicators for air pollution surveillance are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

 

  • Overall best Air Pollution Indicator - SO2
  • Overall best chemical Indicator of Air Pollution - SO2
  • Best biological Indicator of Air Pollution → LICHENS
  • Air Pollution Monitoring → CPCB [Central Pollution Control Board]

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective markers for air pollution surveillance include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. These provide a comprehensive assessment of air quality and are crucial for monitoring the impact on health and the environment.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following physical examination findings can support the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mechanical second heart sound

 

The above scenario, which includes anemia, increased LDH, and hemoglobinuria, as well as schistocytes on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of angiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) caused by red cell trauma. A mechanical second heart sound can help to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a type of hemolytic anemia caused by red cell trauma.

 

Shear forces cause hemolysis in artificial mechanical cardiac valves due to turbulent blood flow and pressure gradients. This traumatic damage causes intravascular hemolysis and the appearance in blood smears of red cell fragments (schistocytes), burr cells, helmet cells, and triangle cells. The same pressure gradients are also responsible for a mechanical heart sound on auscultation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenomegaly: Splenomegaly is often seen in various hemolytic anemias but is not specific for MAHA associated with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option B. Frontal bossing: Frontal bossing is seen in congenital hemolytic anemias such as thalassemia and sickle cell anemia due to extramedullary hematopoiesis, but not typically in MAHA.

 

Option D. Goitre: Goitre is related to thyroid disorders and is not associated with hemolytic anemia or mechanical heart valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, hemoglobinuria, increased LDH, and schistocytes on a peripheral smear, the presence of a mechanical second heart sound can support the diagnosis of angiopathic hemolytic anemia due to mechanical heart valves. The mechanical destruction of red blood cells leads to intravascular hemolysis, characteristic laboratory findings, and specific physical examination findings related to the heart valve.

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Before examining the patient
  2. After examining the patient
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings
  4. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B and C only

 

Healthcare personnel should perform hand hygiene with soap and water when hands are visibly soiled.

 

Healthcare personnel should use an alcohol-based hand rub for the following clinical indications:

 

  • Immediately before touching a patient
  • Before performing an aseptic task (e.g., placing an indwelling device) or handling invasive medical devices
  • Before moving from work on a soiled body site to a clean body site on the same patient
  • After touching a patient or the patient’s immediate environment
  • After contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated surfaces
  • Immediately after glove removal

 

Other Option:

 

D. Hands are visibly soiled: In this case, hand washing with soap and water is recommended rather than using a sanitizer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Healthcare personnel should use hand sanitizer before and after examining a patient and after touching the patient's surroundings. However, when hands are visibly soiled, hand hygiene should be performed using soap and water instead of a sanitizer.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed suction drain

 

The drain shown in the image is a Romovac drain, which is a type of closed suction drain. Closed suction drains are used to remove fluids from a surgical site while maintaining a closed system, preventing contamination and infection. These drains have a bulb or collection reservoir that creates a negative pressure vacuum when compressed, allowing for continuous drainage of fluids from the wound site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open drain: These drains, like Penrose drains, are open systems where fluids drain passively onto a dressing or into a container, which increases the risk of infection due to exposure to the external environment.

 

Option B. Semi-open drain: These drains are a hybrid between open and closed systems, but are not as commonly used as purely open or closed systems.

 

Option D. Penrose drain: This is a type of open drain that allows passive drainage of fluids into the surrounding dressings. It is not connected to any suction mechanism or collection container.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Romovac drain is a closed suction drain that uses a vacuum system to actively remove fluids from a surgical site, reducing the risk of infection and aiding in the healing process.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal edema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Terlipressin plus albumin

 

The patient described has cirrhosis with signs of renal dysfunction, which suggests the possibility of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) (Remember - HRS is the diagnosis of exclusion)

 

HRS is a type of renal failure that occurs in patients with advanced liver disease and is characterized by functional renal failure due to reduced renal blood flow.

 

The initial management for suspected HRS involves stopping all diuretics, as they can exacerbate renal dysfunction.

 

The mainstay of treatment includes the administration of albumin to expand plasma volume and vasoconstrictors to improve renal blood flow. Terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor that is commonly used in combination with albumin to manage HRS. This combination helps to improve renal function by counteracting the splanchnic vasodilation that occurs in cirrhosis, thereby increasing effective arterial blood volume and renal perfusion.

 

Doses – The prescribed dose of albumin is 1 gram per kilogram of body weight per day. The maximum dose should not exceed 100 grams per day. Albumin should be administered for at least 48 hours, equivalent to 2 days.

 

It's important to avoid using normal saline or lactated solutions concurrently because they contain sodium, which could be contraindicated or undesirable in the treatment circumstances requiring albumin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid and is not indicated in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome. It is used for conditions such as autoimmune hepatitis or severe alcoholic hepatitis, but it does not address the pathophysiology of HRS.

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant and is not appropriate in this setting due to the increased risk of bleeding in patients with cirrhosis. It is used for preventing or treating thrombotic conditions but does not play a role in managing HRS.

 

Option C. Torsemide: Torsemide is a loop diuretic and should be discontinued in patients with HRS. Diuretics can worsen renal function in these patients by further decreasing renal perfusion and exacerbating the underlying problem of splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with cirrhosis and suspected hepatorenal syndrome, the appropriate management includes the use of albumin combined with vasoconstrictors like terlipressin to improve renal function and address the underlying hemodynamic changes associated with HRS.

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ligature mark

 

A ligature mark is a well-known pressure mark on the neck underneath a ligature. It is a common injury in cases of hanging and strangulation.

 

Ligature Mark:

 

  • Appearance: Typically presents as a horizontal or slightly diagonal mark around the neck.
  • Cause: Caused by the application of a ligature (e.g., rope, cord, or similar object) under tension.
  • Context: Commonly associated with homicidal, suicidal, or accidental hanging and strangulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graze abrasion: Caused by scraping or sliding friction against a rough surface, resulting in superficial loss of skin.

 

Option C. Brush burns: Result from friction burns, often appearing as red, inflamed, and abraded areas of skin.

 

Option D. Imprint abrasion: Caused by the impact of a patterned object, leaving an imprint on the skin.

 

Educational objective

 

Types of abrasions:

choices.text: Divalent Metal Transporter 1
Divalent Metal Transporter 2

questions.text: What is the transporter of iron into enterocytes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Divalent Metal Transporter 1

 

Explanation

 

Iron uptake into enterocytes is primarily facilitated by the Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1), which actively transports ferrous iron (Fe2+) across the apical membrane of these cells. The process involves several steps:

 

  1. Reduction of Iron: Luminal non-heme iron, predominantly in the ferric (Fe3+) state, must first be reduced to ferrous (Fe2+) iron. This reduction is carried out by ferrireductases like b cytochromes and STEAP3.
  2. Transport via DMT1: Once reduced to Fe2+, iron is transported into the enterocytes through DMT1 located on the apical membrane.
  3. Exit from Enterocytes: After crossing into the enterocyte, Fe2+ destined for the circulation is exported across the basolateral membrane by Ferroportin. This export is coupled with the oxidation of Fe2+ back to Fe3+ by iron oxidases such as hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin 1: Incorrect as Ferroportin is responsible for the export of iron from enterocytes into the blood, not for iron uptake into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Hephaestin: Incorrect because hephaestin is involved in the oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ during iron export from enterocytes, not in the uptake.

 

Option D. Divalent Metal Transporter 2: Incorrect as DMT2 is not the primary transporter involved in the uptake of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the uptake of ferrous iron (Fe2+) into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen, functioning in conjunction with enzymes that reduce ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) iron.

questions.text: How does this graft get nutrition on day 3? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Inosculation

 

In the process of skin graft healing, the nutrition of the graft changes over time:

 

  1. Imbibition (Days 1-2): During the first two days after the graft is placed, it receives nutrition through plasmatic imbibition. This process involves the absorption of nutrients from the wound bed by diffusion into the graft.
  2. Inosculation (Days 3-5): By the third day, inosculation occurs, which involves the connection of blood vessels from the recipient bed to the blood vessels within the graft. This is a crucial step where initial vascular connections start to form between the graft and the recipient site, providing direct blood flow to the graft.
  3. Neovascularisation (After Day 5): After the fifth day, new blood vessels begin to grow into the graft from the recipient bed, a process known as neovascularization. This ensures that the graft has a stable blood supply, enhancing its long-term survival.
  4. Vascular Anastomosis: This term refers to the surgical connection of blood vessels, which is not typically a mechanism involved in the natural healing of skin grafts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imbibition: This occurs primarily in the first two days post-grafting, where the graft absorbs nutrients by diffusion but not through vascular connections.

 

Option C. Neovascularisation: This process begins after the fifth day, contributing to the long-term survival of the graft through the growth of new blood vessels.

 

Option D. Vascular anastomosis: This is not a natural stage of graft healing but refers to the surgical joining of vessels, which is unrelated to the described natural healing stages of grafts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On day 3, a skin graft receives nutrition primarily through inosculation, where early vascular connections form between the graft and the recipient bed, allowing for initial blood supply to the graft.

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Identify the following organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

    
The patient presents with symptoms of urethral discharge and dysuria, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, which strongly suggests a sexually transmitted infection. The image provided shows Gram-negative diplococci, which are characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes symptoms like purulent discharge from the urethra, dysuria, and may be accompanied by other complications if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H. ducreyi: This bacterium causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful ulcers on the genitalia, not typically associated with pus discharge and dysuria as seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Candida: While Candida species can cause infections, they usually lead to candidiasis, presenting with symptoms like itching, discharge, and irritation but not the Gram-negative diplococci seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:


Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonorrhea, characterized by urethral discharge and dysuria, especially following unprotected sexual intercourse.

choices.text: Medial nasal and lateral nasal process

questions.text: The following image is due to defect in fusion of? (FMGE JANUARY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Medial nasal and maxillary process

 

Explanation:

 

Above image is showing Cleft lip; it is due to failure of fusion between the medial nasal and maxillary process.

 

In embryonic development, the face forms from a series of swellings and processes. The medial nasal process contributes to the formation of the middle part of the upper lip, philtrum, and part of the nasal septum. The maxillary process gives rise to the upper jaw and the lateral parts of the upper lip.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Medial Nasal and Lateral Nasal Process: The medial nasal process and lateral nasal process are both involved in the formation of the nose and upper lip. The medial nasal process contributes to the middle part of the upper lip and part of the nasal septum. The lateral nasal process forms the sides of the nose.

 

Option C)  Maxillary and Mandibular Process: The maxillary process, as mentioned earlier, contributes to the upper jaw and lateral parts of the upper lip. The mandibular process, on the other hand, forms the lower jaw or mandible. These two processes are essential for the formation of the upper and lower jaws, respectively.

 

Option D) Lateral Nasal and Maxillary Process: The lateral nasal process, as mentioned earlier, contributes to the sides of the nose. The maxillary process, as mentioned earlier, forms the upper jaw and lateral parts of the upper lip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLEFT LIP VS CLEFT LIP AND CLEFT PALATE.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

 

 

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve, which innervates various muscles in the sole of the foot. It divides into superficial and deep branches, each supplying specific muscles.

 

  • Flexor Digitorum Accessorius : This muscle assists in the flexion of the toes and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • First Interossei: The interossei muscles, which include the dorsal and plantar interossei, are responsible for abduction and adduction of the toes. The first interossei is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Abductor hallucis: This muscle is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, not the lateral plantar nerve.

 

3. Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is also supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

4. First lumbrical: The first lumbrical is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, whereas the second, third, and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the public tubercle. X-ray show intestinal obstruction. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

This type of hernia occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where the abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal. It is more common in women, especially those with repeated pregnancies. The description of the swelling's location lateral and below the pubic tubercle fits well with a femoral hernia. If the hernia becomes strangulated, it means that the blood supply to the herniated tissue is compromised, leading to severe pain, vomiting, and signs of intestinal obstruction as seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adhesions: Bands of fibrous tissue that can form between abdominal tissues and organs, often as a result of surgery can lead to intestinal obstruction if they cause the intestines to twist or kink. However, adhesions themselves do not cause noticeable swelling as described in the scenario.

 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: This will present with a swelling above the pubic tubercle.

 

Option D. Appendicular mass: This refers to a mass formed from a swollen, inflamed appendix often associated with appendicitis. While this can lead to pain and vomiting, the location of the pain and swelling typically would be around the lower right quadrant of the abdomen, not below the pubic tubercle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the location of the swelling and the associated symptoms, the most probable diagnosis is a Strangulated Femoral Hernia. This condition requires prompt surgical intervention to relieve the obstruction and restore blood flow to the entrapped tissues to prevent further complications such as tissue necrosis.

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inhaled lead dust

 

  • In industrial environments such as battery manufacturing factories, the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption is through inhalation of lead dust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic

 

  • Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol/vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical picture of lead poisoning:

 

  • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • Lead encephalopathy
  • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).

 

Treatment: EDTA

choices.text: Epithelial cell tumor
Germ cell tumor
Sex cord stromal tumor
Granulosa cell tumor

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell tumor

 

Explanation:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified under epithelial cell tumors. Epithelial ovarian tumors originate from the cells that line the surface of the ovary. Clear cell carcinoma is a subtype of epithelial ovarian tumors.

 

Classification of ovarian tumors:

 

  1. Epithelial Cell Tumor
    • Serous
    • Mucinous
    • Brenner
    • Clear cell
    • Endometrioid
    • Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category.
  2. Germ Cell Tumor
    • Dysgerminoma
    • Yolk sac tumor
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma
    • Embryonal
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here.
  3. Sex Cord Stromal Tumor
    • Granulosa cell tumor
    • Thecoma
    • Fibroma
    • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.

 

Educational Objective:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified as an epithelial cell tumor.

 

Ref: Page no 291, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

 

The image shown is of Whipple’s procedure, which can be done for distal cholangiocarcinoma.

 

  • Whipple's procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a complex surgical procedure that involves removing the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the common bile duct, the gallbladder, and sometimes a portion of the stomach.
  • This procedure is typically performed to treat cancer of the pancreas, duodenum, or the ampulla of Vater

 

Distal cholangiocarcinoma is cancer that occurs in the bile ducts, typically in the lower part of the bile duct near the pancreas. The procedure referred to in the question is often associated with the surgical management of distal cholangiocarcinoma. It involves a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy), which is a complex surgical procedure to remove the affected part of the bile duct, pancreas, and small intestine, and then reconstruct the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advanced gastric carcinoma: The management of advanced gastric carcinoma typically involves various approaches, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Surgical procedures such as gastrectomy or lymphadenectomy may be performed depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

 

Option B. Gallbladder carcinoma: Gallbladder carcinoma may be treated with surgical resection, often involving cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) and potentially more extensive procedures if the cancer has spread. However, the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to gallbladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. Chronic calcific pancreatitis: Chronic calcific pancreatitis may require surgical intervention in certain cases, but the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to this condition. Surgical options for chronic pancreatitis may include drainage procedures or resection of the affected pancreatic tissue.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The procedure mentioned in the question, which is often performed to manage distal cholangiocarcinoma, is a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy).

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Acute myeloid leukemia
Chronic myelogenous leukemia

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

 

The peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

The blood contains large numbers of small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells are usually disrupted in the process of making smears, producing so-called smudge cells. Lymphocytes are of same size and configuration with a uniform appearance called as "convent-girl" appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): The peripheral smear in ALL typically shows a high number of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. There would be an absence of smudge cells, which are characteristic of CLL.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML is characterized by the presence of myeloblasts in the peripheral blood smear. These cells are larger, have more cytoplasm, and may contain Auer rods. Again, smudge cells are not a feature of AML.

 

Option D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): The peripheral smear in CML shows a full spectrum of myeloid cells, from myeloblasts to mature neutrophils, often with an increase in basophils and eosinophils. Smudge cells are not a characteristic finding in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A baby is diagnosed with B cell leukemia. All of the following are good prognostic factors except: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Hyperdiploidy
  2. Age < 1 year
  3. t(9;22)
  4. t(4;11)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) is a common type of leukemia in children. Prognostic factors play a crucial role in determining the treatment plan and overall outcomes for patients.

 

2. Age < 1 year: Age less than 1 year is considered a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. Infants with B-ALL typically have a higher risk of relapse and a poorer response to therapy.

 

3. t(9;22): This translocation involves the Philadelphia chromosome, which is generally associated with poor prognosis in B-ALL. It leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion protein, which is a marker of poor prognosis.

 

4. t(4;11): This translocation is associated with rearrangements of the MLL (Mixed-Lineage Leukemia) gene, which is a poor prognostic factor in B-ALL. It is commonly seen in infants and is associated with a poor outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Hyperdiploidy: Hyperdiploidy (>50 chromosomes) is actually a good prognostic factor in B-ALL. Children with hyperdiploid B-ALL generally have a better response to therapy and a higher overall survival rate.

 

Thus, the factors B (Age < 1 year), C (t(9;22)), and D (t(4;11)) are all poor prognostic indicators, and only A (Hyperdiploidy) is a good prognostic factor.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with pellagra-like symptoms. There was no history of flushing and urinary 5-HIAA levels were normal. Family history of similar illness was noted. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective transport of neutral or non-polar amino acids, particularly tryptophan, in the intestines and kidneys. This defect leads to decreased absorption and increased urinary excretion of these amino acids, resulting in tryptophan deficiency. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (vitamin B3), serotonin, and melatonin. Deficiency in tryptophan can therefore lead to niacin deficiency, manifesting as pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Unlike Fanconi syndrome, which is characterized by non-selective amino aciduria (excretion of various amino acids including proline, hydroxyproline, and arginine), Hartnup disease typically shows selective amino aciduria, primarily affecting tryptophan and similar neutral amino acids.

 

Key indicators in this case include:

 

  • Pellagra-like symptoms: Dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, commonly associated with niacin deficiency.
  • No history of flushing and normal urinary 5-HIAA levels: These findings rule out carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by flushing and elevated 5-HIAA levels due to serotonin overproduction.
  • Family history of similar illness: Suggests a genetic disorder, consistent with the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern of Hartnup disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid: Typically presents with flushing, diarrhea, and elevated urinary 5-HIAA levels due to serotonin overproduction. These findings are absent here.

 

Option C. Nutritional pellagra: Caused by dietary niacin deficiency. The presence of a family history of similar symptoms makes a genetic cause more likely than a nutritional deficiency.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: A benign condition caused by a defect in fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. It does not cause pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hartnup disease should be considered in patients with pellagra-like symptoms, particularly if there is a family history of similar symptoms and no evidence of carcinoid syndrome or nutritional deficiency. 

 

Elevated levels of neutral amino acids like tryptophan in the urine are a hallmark of Hartnup disease, indicating an issue with amino acid reabsorption in the kidneys.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure in the ear, the surgeon injured a nerve which led to lagophthalmos after the surgery. Which nerve was likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cranial nerve 7

 

Lagophthalmos is the inability to fully close the eyelids, typically due to paralysis of the orbicularis oculi muscle. This muscle is innervated by the facial nerve, also known as Cranial Nerve 7. During ear surgery, the facial nerve can be vulnerable to injury, especially in procedures involving the middle ear or mastoid region. Damage to this nerve results in a loss of motor control to the muscles of facial expression, including those responsible for eyelid closure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial nerve 8: It is vestibulo cochlear nerve which is having the function of hearing & equilibrium

 

Option C. Cranial nerve 6: The sixth cranial nerve, or abducens nerve, controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for eye abduction. Injury to this nerve causes problems with lateral eye movement, not with eyelid closure, making it an incorrect choice.

 

Option D. Cranial nerve 5: The fifth cranial nerve, or trigeminal nerve, is primarily responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing. While it has a minor role in reflexive blinking (via the corneal reflex), it does not control the orbicularis oculi muscle, so its injury would not cause lagophthalmos.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial nerve (Cranial Nerve 7) controls the muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi muscle, and injury to this nerve can result in lagophthalmos.
